clusters.title: Illinois, Chicago sue to block National Guard, but troops already deployed
clusters.neutral_headline: Illinois and Chicago Sue to Block National Guard Deployment

items.title: Illinois, Chicago sue to block National Guard, but troops already deployed
items.standfirst: Illinois and Chicago have sued the Trump administration to block deployment of the National Guard to Chicago, though it was revealed in court that troops are already on the way.
items.content: Illinois and Chicago have sued the Trump administration to block deployment of the National Guard to Chicago, though it was revealed in court that troops are already on the way.

items.title: Republicans post fake image of Oregon protest – using photos of South America
items.standfirst: A federal judge had blocked Trump’s request to deploy California national guard to Portland Before a federal judge blocked Donald Trump from putting members of California’s national guard on the streets of Portland, Oregon, late on Sunday, the state’s Republican party welcomed the planned deployment in celebratory posts on social media.“President Trump on Sunday deployed 300 California National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon after a judge ruled that the Oregon National Guard could not be deployed to keep federal facilities and personnel in Portland safe,” Oregon Republicans wrote on their official Facebook, Instagram and X accounts. Continue reading...
items.content: A federal judge had blocked Trump’s request to deploy California national guard to Portland Before a federal judge blocked Donald Trump from putting members of California’s national guard on the streets of Portland, Oregon, late on Sunday, the state’s Republican party welcomed the planned deployment in celebratory posts on social media.“President Trump on Sunday deployed 300 California National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon after a judge ruled that the Oregon National Guard could not be deployed to keep federal facilities and personnel in Portland safe,” Oregon Republicans wrote on their official Facebook, Instagram and X accounts. items.standfirst: President Trump suggested Monday he may use the Insurrection Act if courts continue to bar him from deploying the National Guard across the U.S. Why it matters: Trump would be the first president in more than 60 years to use the 1807 Act that allows the deployment of U.S. troops to quell domestic…

items.title: Reporter's Notebook: When Trump tests presidential power
items.standfirst: As President Trump tests the limits of presidential power, how much of his claims are built on fact -- and how much on fiction? "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.
items.content: As President Trump tests the limits of presidential power, how much of his claims are built on fact -- and how much on fiction? "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.

items.title: Judge blocks Trump administration from sending National Guard troops to Oregon
items.standfirst: A federal judge temporarily blocked the Trump administration from deploying any National Guard units to Oregon after a legal whirlwind that began hours earlier when the president sent California troops to Portland.
items.content: A federal judge temporarily blocked the Trump administration from deploying any National Guard units to Oregon after a legal whirlwind that began hours earlier when the president sent California troops to Portland.

items.title: Breaking down dispute over Trump's latest National Guard deployment
items.standfirst: A federal judge in Oregon has temporarily blocked President Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, and an Illinois judge is weighing whether to block troops from entering Chicago. Nicole Sganga has details.
items.content: A federal judge in Oregon has temporarily blocked President Trump from deploying National Guard troops to Portland, Oregon, and an Illinois judge is weighing whether to block troops from entering Chicago. Nicole Sganga has details.

Illinois sued the administration to stop plans to send in 400 troops from Texas. It comes after a separate judge blocked Trump from sending…

items.standfirst: Trump insists the troops are needed to instill order, but Democratic states say the deployments risk escalating tensions.
items.content: Trump insists the troops are needed to instill order, but Democratic states say the deployments risk escalating tensions.

items.title: Federal judge declines to immediately block National Guard deployment in Illinois
items.standfirst: Illinois asked a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending Guard members from other states, but the judge declined to do so, for now.
items.content: Illinois asked a judge to block the Trump administration from federalizing the Illinois National Guard and from sending Guard members from other states, but the judge declined to do so, for now.(Image credit: Mathieu Lewis-Rolland/Getty Images; Vincent Alban/Getty Images; Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images)

ai_summary: Illinois and Chicago filed a lawsuit to prevent the National Guard deployment.

The situation involves the use of federal power and presidential authority.
The legal battle highlights the limits of presidential power.

items.title: AI chipmaker AMD strikes major deal with OpenAI

OpenAI, the company behind major AI platform ChatGPT, announced a deal for AMD to provide the AI startup with its high-performance processing chips starting next year. Jo Ling Kent discusses the impact.

items.title: AMD's Chip Deal With OpenAI Triggers Explosive Rally | Bloomberg Tech 10/6/2025
items.standfirst: AMD CEO Lisa Su and OpenAI President Greg Brockman join Bloomberg Tech to weigh in on the two companies' deal to roll out AI infrastructure, a pact the chipmaker said could generate tens of billions of dollars in new revenue. Plus, White House AI and Crypto Czar David Sacks defends the Trump administration’s approach to China in the context of the global AI race, and Meta CMO Alex Schultz has a new book on how AI is changing the advertising landscape. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: AMD CEO Lisa Su and OpenAI President Greg Brockman join Bloomberg Tech to weigh in on the two companies' deal to roll out AI infrastructure, a pact the chipmaker said could generate tens of billions of dollars in new revenue. Plus, White House AI and Crypto Czar David Sacks defends the Trump administration’s approach to China in the context of the global AI race, and Meta CMO Alex Schultz has a new book on how AI is changing the advertising landscape. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: OpenAI signs multibillion-dollar chip deal with AMD
items.standfirst: The deal offers the ChatGPT maker an opportunity to buy a 10% stake in chipmaker AMD OpenAI and the chipmaker AMD announced on Monday that they had signed a multibillion-dollar chip deal that would also give the ChatGPT creator the option to buy a large stake in the chipmaker.The deal offers OpenAI an opportunity to buy 10% in AMD and marks a major vote of confidence in the company’s AI chips and software. Shares of AMD surged more than 30% and added about $80bn to its market capitalization after the announcement. Continue reading...
items.content: The deal offers the ChatGPT maker an opportunity to buy a 10% stake in chipmaker AMD OpenAI and the chipmaker AMD announced on Monday that they had signed a multibillion-dollar chip deal that would also give the ChatGPT creator the option to buy a large stake in the chipmaker.The deal offers OpenAI an opportunity to buy 10% in AMD and marks a major vote of confidence in the company’s AI chips and software. Shares of AMD surged more than 30% and added about $80bn to its market capitalization after the announcement. Continue reading...

items.title: Market Only Looking at Positives of AMD, OpenAI Deal, Says Analyst Goldberg
items.standfirst: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. signed a deal with OpenAI for AI infrastructure that could generate tens of billions of dollars in new revenue over multiple years. Jay Goldberg, senior analyst at Seaport, examines the deal on “Bloomberg Surveillance.” (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Stranded Mount Everest hikers being evacuated
clusters.neutral_headline: Blizzard on Mount Everest Strands Hundreds of Hikers

items.title: Stranded Mount Everest hikers being evacuated
items.standfirst: More than 200 people left stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest are being evacuated, Reuters news agency reports.
items.content: More than 200 people left stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of Mount Everest are being evacuated, Reuters news agency reports.

items.title: Rescuers race to reach hundreds stranded on Mount Everest by blizzard
items.standfirst: Rescuers are racing against time to reach hundreds of stranded hikers on Mount Everest after a blizzard hit unexpectedly. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer has the very latest.
items.content: Rescuers are racing against time to reach hundreds of stranded hikers on Mount Everest after a blizzard hit unexpectedly. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer has the very latest.

items.title: Snowstorm traps hundreds of hikers on Mount Everest during China's national holiday
items.standfirst: Rescuers were helping hundreds of hikers trapped by heavy snow at tourist campsites on a slope of Mount Everest in Tibet, Chinese state media said. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Carl Cater, Associate Professor in Tourism Marketing at Swansea University, says many of the tourists caught in the storm were ill equipped and lack the outdoor skills necessary to face the challenge of hiking up the world's tallest mountain.
items.content: Rescuers were helping hundreds of hikers trapped by heavy snow at tourist campsites on a slope of Mount Everest in Tibet, Chinese state media said. Speaking on FRANCE 24, Carl Cater, Associate Professor in Tourism Marketing at Swansea University, says many of the tourists caught in the storm were ill equipped and lack the outdoor skills necessary to face the challenge of hiking up the world's tallest mountain.

items.title: 'I was lucky to get out': Everest hikers battle hypothermia as blizzard rescue continues
items.standfirst: At least one hiker has died and hundreds are still stranded near the mountain's eastern face.
items.content: At least one hiker has died and hundreds are still stranded near the mountain's eastern face.

items.title: More than 200 hikers still stranded as blizzard hits Mount Everest
items.standfirst: Chinese rescuers were on Monday rushing to evacuate hundreds of hikers stranded on the eastern slope of the world's highest mountain, Mount Everest, after heavy snowfall blanketed campsites over the weekend
items.content: Chinese rescuers were on Monday rushing to evacuate hundreds of hikers stranded on the eastern slope of the world's highest mountain, Mount Everest, after heavy snowfall blanketed campsites over the weekend

items.title: Mount Everest hikers describe ‘extreme’ conditions as huge rescue effort continues
items.standfirst: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holidayTrekkers have described facing “extreme” conditions after an unseasonable snowstorm during one of China’s busiest holiday weekends stranded hundreds of people on Mount Everest, prompting a massive rescue effort.Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border. Continue reading...
items.content: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holidayTrekkers have described facing “extreme” conditions after an unseasonable snowstorm during one of China’s busiest holiday weekends stranded hundreds of people on Mount Everest, prompting a massive rescue effort.Chinese authorities said about 350 people had made their way down but at least 200 remained stranded at the Everest Scenic Area, to the east of the mountain, on the Tibetan side of the border. Continue reading...

items.title: Watch: Race to reach hikers stranded by Mount Everest blizzard
items.standfirst: Chinese state media reports say around 350 people have been rescued and efforts are under way to reach more than 200 others.
items.content: Chinese state media reports say around 350 people have been rescued and efforts are under way to reach more than 200 others.

items.title: Mount Everest rescue under way after snowstorm traps nearly 1,000 people
items.standfirst: Hundreds of trekkers stranded by blizzard on eastern face of mountain in Tibet already guided to safety by rescuersRescue efforts are under way on Mount Everest after a snowstorm trapped nearly 1,000 people in campsites on the eastern side of the mountain, according to Chinese state media.Hundreds of trekkers stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of the mountain in Tibet were guided to safety by rescuers on Sunday, as unusually heavy precipitation including rain pummelled the Himalayas. Continue reading...
items.content: Hundreds of trekkers stranded by blizzard on eastern face of mountain in Tibet already guided to safety by rescuersRescue efforts are under way on Mount Everest after a snowstorm trapped nearly 1,000 people in campsites on the eastern side of the mountain, according to Chinese state media.Hundreds of trekkers stranded by a blizzard near the eastern face of the mountain in Tibet were guided to safety by rescuers on Sunday, as unusually heavy precipitation including rain pummelled the Himalayas. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A blizzard near Mount Everest stranded over 200 hikers.
Rescuers are working to reach the stranded individuals.
The storm hit during China's national holiday.
Some hikers lacked proper equipment and skills.
At least one hiker has died due to the conditions.

clusters.title: Hamas and Israel begin indirect talks to end devastating war in Gaza
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel and Hamas Begin Indirect Talks to End Gaza War

items.title: Hamas and Israel begin indirect talks to end devastating war in Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas launched indirect talks in Egypt for a potential ceasefire. The first phase of the U.S.-drafted peace plan calls for the release of the Israeli hostages in exchange for the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops. A second phase envisions the end of the war and a lasting governance…
items.content: Israel and Hamas launched indirect talks in Egypt for a potential ceasefire. The first phase of the U.S.-drafted peace plan calls for the release of the Israeli hostages in exchange for the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops. A second phase envisions the end of the war and a lasting governance…

items.title: Gaza plan needs 'awful lot of gap-filling and an implementation, enforcement mechanism'
items.standfirst: Israeli and Hamas officials are holding indirect talks in an Egyptian coastal resort on Monday on a U.S-drafted peace plan to end the war in Gaza on the eve of its second anniversary. The talks focus on the ceasefire's first stage, including the partial withdrawal of Israeli forces as well as the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli detention, according to a Hamas statement. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Nomi Bar-Yaacov, International Negotiator, Mediator, Fellow at the Global Fellowship Initiative at the Geneva Centre for Security Policy.
items.content: Israeli and Hamas officials are holding indirect talks in an Egyptian coastal resort on Monday on a U.S-drafted peace plan to end the war in Gaza on the eve of its second anniversary. The talks focus on the ceasefire's first stage, including the partial withdrawal of Israeli forces as well as the release of hostages held by militants in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli detention, according to a Hamas statement. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Nomi Bar-Yaacov, International Negotiator, Mediator, Fellow at the Global Fellowship Initiative at the Geneva Centre for Security Policy.

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza war
items.standfirst: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks in Egypt, raising hopes of ceasefire and prisoner swap
items.standfirst: Israeli, Hamas and American delegations were due in Egypt to discuss a 20-point peace plan tabled by President Donald Trump to halt the conflict.
items.content: Israeli, Hamas and American delegations were due in Egypt to discuss a 20-point peace plan tabled by President Donald Trump to halt the conflict.

items.title: Trump urges negotiators to ‘move fast’ as Gaza ceasefire talks set to begin in Egypt
items.standfirst: Talks on Monday expected to focus on release of hostages and end to war, after Israel kills 63 people in Gaza in past dayDonald Trump has urged negotiators to “move fast” in talks focused on the release of hostages held by Hamas in Gaza and a broader end to the war, as representatives arrived in Egypt for discussions set to begin on Monday.The talks will focus on the first phase of Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza, the Egyptian foreign ministry said, which is the release of the remaining 48 hostages held by Hamas in return for Palestinian prisoners held in Israel. Continue reading...
items.content: Talks on Monday expected to focus on release of hostages and end to war, after Israel kills 63 people in Gaza in past dayDonald Trump has urged negotiators to “move fast” in talks focused on the release of hostages held by Hamas in Gaza and a broader end to the war, as representatives arrived in Egypt for discussions set to begin on Monday.The talks will focus on the first phase of Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza, the Egyptian foreign ministry said, which is the release of the remaining 48 hostages held by Hamas in return for Palestinian prisoners held in Israel. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israel and Hamas started indirect talks in Egypt.
The talks aim to achieve a ceasefire in Gaza.
The U.S.-drafted plan includes hostage release and troop withdrawal.
Negotiations focus on the first phase of the peace plan.
Hopes for ending the nearly two-year war are rising.

clusters.title: A '48-hour deadline and a final chance' for Lecornu after French PM resigns
clusters.neutral_headline: A '48-hour deadline and a final chance' for Lecornu after French PM resigns

items.title: A '48-hour deadline and a final chance' for Lecornu after French PM resigns
items.standfirst: Reporting from outside the Élysée presidential palace, FRANCE 24's Clovis Casali says President Emmanuel Macron has given Sébastien Lecornu a 48-hour deadline to form a government. An adviser to the president told reporters that Macron would "do the responsible thing" if no solution was found to end this political deadlock by Wednesday night. "In other words, he could call for a snap parliamentary elections," notes Casali.
items.content: Reporting from outside the Élysée presidential palace, FRANCE 24's Clovis Casali says President Emmanuel Macron has given Sébastien Lecornu a 48-hour deadline to form a government. An adviser to the president told reporters that Macron would "do the responsible thing" if no solution was found to end this political deadlock by Wednesday night. "In other words, he could call for a snap parliamentary elections," notes Casali.

items.title: France in fresh political and market turmoil after prime minister resigns
items.standfirst: Sébastien Lecornu, who quit on Monday, is asked by Emmanuel Macron to quickly negotiate a stability plan
items.content: Sébastien Lecornu, who quit on Monday, is asked by Emmanuel Macron to quickly negotiate a stability plan

items.title: 'We must be grown-ups today': French MP Eléonore Caroit asserts it's 'our duty' to seek way forward
items.standfirst: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move plunged the country further into political crisis and left President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Eléonore Caroit, a member of President Emmanuel Macron’s Renaissance party and an MP for French citizens living abroad, tells FRANCE 24 that she does not support a call for snap elections. “Do I think it's going to be any different if we call for elections today? I'm afraid it won't be radically different," she notes. "What we're seeing is that we have a divided country with a divided representation, and it is our duty as MPs to actually find a way [forward].”
items.content: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move plunged the country further into political crisis and left President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Eléonore Caroit, a member of President Emmanuel Macron’s Renaissance party and an MP for French citizens living abroad, tells FRANCE 24 that she does not support a call for snap elections. “Do I think it's going to be any different if we call for elections today? I'm afraid it won't be radically different," she notes. "What we're seeing is that we have a divided country with a divided representation, and it is our duty as MPs to actually find a way [forward].”

items.title: 'French politics has always been baroque, but now it's playing out on the public stage'
items.standfirst: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move has plunged the country further into political crisis, leaving embattled French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Lecornu is now the shortest-serving prime minister in the history of the Fifth Republic. French politics have been in disarray since 2024 snap elections. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Genie Godula welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.
items.content: France’s new Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after less than a month in office and less than 24 hours after naming a new government that prompted a key coalition ally to withdraw support. The move has plunged the country further into political crisis, leaving embattled French President Emmanuel Macron with few options. Lecornu is now the shortest-serving prime minister in the history of the Fifth Republic. French politics have been in disarray since 2024 snap elections. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Genie Godula welcomes Paul Smith, Associate Professor in French History and Politics at the University of Nottingham.

items.title: A mess of Macron's making? France in crisis as latest government falls in 14 hours
items.standfirst: Emmanuel Macron losing his third prime minister, in the 16 months since he dissolved parliament and lost ensuing snap elections. Sebastien Lecornu breaking a Fifth Republic record by lasting just 27 days as head of government.
items.content: Emmanuel Macron losing his third prime minister, in the 16 months since he dissolved parliament and lost ensuing snap elections. Sebastien Lecornu breaking a Fifth Republic record by lasting just 27 days as head of government.

items.title: France in fresh political crisis as PM Lecornu quits after 26 days
items.standfirst: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.
items.content: Lecornu was asked by President Macron to stay on until Wednesday in a last-ditch attempt to achieve "stability" for the country.

items.title: France is in crisis but bond markets leave other governments at risk of meltdown too
items.standfirst: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political mathsMacron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to avoid political crisisWhat happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?Sébastien Lecornu’s abrupt resignation as the French prime minister on Monday after less than a month in the role marked the latest clash between France’s stretched public finances and its polarised politics.Lecornu was the latest prime minister to try and fail to cobble together a package of spending cuts and tax rises that would pass muster in a parliament without a clear majority, and contain mounting bond market pressures. Continue reading...
items.content: Investors rattled by resignation of French PM but country is not alone in trying to grapple with political mathsMacron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to avoid political crisisWhat happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?Sébastien Lecornu’s abrupt resignation as the French prime minister on Monday after less than a month in the role marked the latest clash between France’s stretched public finances and its polarised politics.Lecornu was the latest prime minister to try and fail to cobble together a package of spending cuts and tax rises that would pass muster in a parliament without a clear majority, and contain mounting bond market pressures. Continue reading...

items.title: France's President Macron gives outgoing PM Lecornu one last chance
items.standfirst: France's new prime minister resigned on Monday after less than a month in office, sinking the country further into a political crisis and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron to find a way out of the deadlock. As a response, the President asked outgoing PM Lecornu to hold 'final talks' and attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday. Story by Marc Perelman.
items.content: France's new prime minister resigned on Monday after less than a month in office, sinking the country further into a political crisis and piling pressure on President Emmanuel Macron to find a way out of the deadlock. As a response, the President asked outgoing PM Lecornu to hold 'final talks' and attempt to solve the situation by Wednesday. Story by Marc Perelman.

items.title: France's Macron tasks outgoing PM Lecornu to hold final talks to stabilize country
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron has asked outgoing Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to hold final talks by Wednesday evening with political parties to stabilise the country, Macron's office said on Monday. Earlier on Monday, Lecornu offered his and his newly formed government's resignation after allies and foes alike had threatened to topple the government. Deatails by FRANCE 24 reporter Clovis Casali.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron has asked outgoing Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu to hold final talks by Wednesday evening with political parties to stabilise the country, Macron's office said on Monday. Earlier on Monday, Lecornu offered his and his newly formed government's resignation after allies and foes alike had threatened to topple the government. Deatails by FRANCE 24 reporter Clovis Casali.

items.title: Macron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to resolve political crisis
items.standfirst: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’Explainer: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what could happen next?Hours after France’s new prime minister resigned less than a month after he was appointed, Emmanuel Macron has asked him to stay on for two more days in a last-ditch effort to chart a way out of the country’s rapidly deepening political crisis.The French president on Monday evening gave Sébastien Lecornu – who had earlier become the third prime minister of the EU’s second-biggest economy to quit in a year – 48 hours to “conduct final negotiations … to define a platform for action and stability”. Continue reading...
items.content: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’Explainer: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what could happen next?Hours after France’s new prime minister resigned less than a month after he was appointed, Emmanuel Macron has asked him to stay on for two more days in a last-ditch effort to chart a way out of the country’s rapidly deepening political crisis.The French president on Monday evening gave Sébastien Lecornu – who had earlier become the third prime minister of the EU’s second-biggest economy to quit in a year – 48 hours to “conduct final negotiations … to define a platform for action and stability”. Continue reading...

items.title: France: President Macron under pressure after fifth PM in two years resigns
items.standfirst: Prime minister Sébastien Lecornu has resigned, creating a political earthquake in France. Lecornu was Prime minister for under a month, and was the fifth to hold the post in two years. His resignation renewed the focus on France's President, Emmanuel Macron, who is under pressure to act to resolve the crisis, by either dissolving the National Assembly, like he did last year, or quitting himself. Story by Charlotte Lam and France 2.
items.content: Prime minister Sébastien Lecornu has resigned, creating a political earthquake in France. Lecornu was Prime minister for under a month, and was the fifth to hold the post in two years. His resignation renewed the focus on France's President, Emmanuel Macron, who is under pressure to act to resolve the crisis, by either dissolving the National Assembly, like he did last year, or quitting himself. Story by Charlotte Lam and France 2.

ai_summary: French Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned after a short tenure.
President Macron gave Lecornu a 48-hour deadline to form a government.
The political situation has caused market and political turmoil.
A key coalition ally withdrew support for the new government.
The country faces a divided government and potential snap elections.

clusters.title: ICC convicts first Darfur militia leader for war crimes
clusters.neutral_headline: ICC convicts first Darfur militia leader for war crimes

items.title: ICC convicts first Darfur militia leader for war crimes
items.standfirst: In tonight's edition, the International Criminal Court convicted the first Janjaweed militia leader for atrocities committed in Sudan's Darfur region more than 20 years ago. Also, Senegal’s Pink Lake, is increasingly drawing the attention of property developers. And Africa Week UK has its inaugural gathering amidst Britain's black history month.
items.content: In tonight's edition, the International Criminal Court convicted the first Janjaweed militia leader for atrocities committed in Sudan's Darfur region more than 20 years ago. Also, Senegal’s Pink Lake, is increasingly drawing the attention of property developers. And Africa Week UK has its inaugural gathering amidst Britain's black history month.

items.title: ICC finds former Sudan militia leader guilty of war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: The International Criminal Court in The Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.
items.content: The International Criminal Court in The Hague handed down its first-ever Darfur war crimes conviction, finding Janjaweed leader Ali Kushayb, guilty of atrocities committed more than two decades ago.(Image credit: Koen Van Weel)

items.title: ICC convicts former Sudan militia leader for war crimes in Darfur
items.standfirst: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocitiesThe international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan. Continue reading...
items.content: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocitiesThe international criminal court has convicted a leader of the Janjaweed militia of playing a leading role in a campaign of atrocities committed in the Sudanese region of Darfur more than 20 years ago.It was the first time the court had convicted a suspect of crimes in Darfur. The court ruled that the atrocities, including mass murders and rapes, were part of a government plan to snuff out a rebellion in the western region of Sudan. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The ICC convicted a Darfur militia leader for war crimes.
The crimes occurred in Sudan's Darfur region over 20 years ago.
The conviction is the first of its kind by the ICC.
The atrocities included mass murders and rapes.
The court found the atrocities part of a government plan.

items.title: No air traffic control crew at busy LA airport amid government shutdown staffing crunch
items.standfirst: Air traffic to the Hollywood Burbank Airport would be remotely managed for six hours on Monday night causing delays for travellersHollywood Burbank Airport in Los Angeles will have no air traffic control staff for nearly six hours on Monday evening, as the effects of the US government shutdown rippled across the country.From 4.15pm until 10pm the Federal Aviation Administration anticipates there will be no air traffic controllers in their tower, although the FAA has said it is trying to bring in staffing sooner than that, according to ABC News. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.standfirst: African kingdom receives second group of third-country nationals in what NGOs and lawyers say is violation of human rightsTen people deported by the US have arrived in Eswatini, its government said, the second group of third-country deportees to be sent to the southern African kingdom by the Trump administration in what lawyers and NGOs have described as violations of their human rights.A statement by the Eswatini government posted on social media before their arrival on Monday said: “The individuals will be kept in a secured area separate from the public, while arrangements are made for their return to their countries of origin.” Continue reading...

items.content: Madagascar’s President Andry Rajoelina on Monday named an army general as prime minister in a bid to calm growing unrest over his rule. Security forces fired tear gas to disperse hundreds of protesters in the capital Antananarivo, injuring at least one, according to AFP reporters.

items.title: Tory plan to scrap judge-led Sentencing Council criticised as ‘bonkers’
items.standfirst: Ex-Conservative ministers denounce Robert Jenrick’s intention to abolish body that develops court guidelinesA Conservative plan to abolish the judge-led Sentencing Council and hand its powers to the Ministry of Justice has been described as “bonkers”, “unimplementable” and “potentially dangerous” by former Tory ministers.The shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick will announce on Tuesday that the independent public body responsible for developing guidelines for judges and magistrates in England and Wales would be closed down by a future Conservative government because it was “not fit for purpose”. Continue reading...
items.content: Ex-Conservative ministers denounce Robert Jenrick’s intention to abolish body that develops court guidelinesA Conservative plan to abolish the judge-led Sentencing Council and hand its powers to the Ministry of Justice has been described as “bonkers”, “unimplementable” and “potentially dangerous” by former Tory ministers.The shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick will announce on Tuesday that the independent public body responsible for developing guidelines for judges and magistrates in England and Wales would be closed down by a future Conservative government because it was “not fit for purpose”. Continue reading...

clusters.neutral_headline: CBS News Names Bari Weiss as Editor-in-Chief

items.title: Who is Bari Weiss? CBS News' new editor-in-chief is a vocal critic of legacy media
items.standfirst: Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media. Here's what to know as she takes the helm of CBS News.
items.content: Provocative columnist Bari Weiss publicly quit the New York Times in 2020, then cofounded The Free Press as an alternative to legacy media. Here's what to know as she takes the helm of CBS News.(Image credit: Leigh Vogel)

items.title: CBS News names Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief
items.standfirst: Paramount Skydance also acquired The Free Press, which Weiss co-founded in 2021.
items.content: Bari Weiss, co-founder and CEO of The Free Press, has been appointed CBS News’ editor-in-chief, Paramount announced on Monday. The Free Press will now operate under the company as well. It’s a major move from the company, which merged with Skydance Corp. in August under CEO David Ellison. Under Ellison, the company has made several strategic acquisitions and is reportedly exploring acquiring Warner Bros. Discovery. “This move is part of Paramount’s bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects – directly and passionately – to audiences around the world,” Ellison said in a statement. “We believe the majority of the country longs for news that is balanced and fact-based, and we want CBS to be their home.” Though she will remain CEO and editor-in-chief of The Free Press, Weiss will report directly to Ellison. The Free Press will maintain its own independent brand and operations, the company said. Weiss and her wife, Nellie Bowles, launched The Free Press in 2021 with Weiss’ sister Suzy. She was previously an opinion writer for The New York Times. Partnering with Paramount, Weiss said, allows The Free Press to expand its audience of 1.5 million. “The values that we’ve hammered out here over the years—journalism based in curiosity and honesty, a culture of healthy disagreement, our shared belief in America’s promise—now have the opportunity to go very, very big,” Weiss wrote in a blog post on The Free Press. Earlier this year, CBS and Paramount settled a $16 million lawsuit with President Donald Trump over a “60 Minutes” interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris. Paramount then hired an ombudsman to analyze bias in CBS reporting. Weiss said she believes in Ellison and “the entire leadership team who took over Paramount this summer.” She added that they plan to make CBS “the most trusted news organization of the 21st Century.”

ai_summary: Bari Weiss, a vocal critic of legacy media, is the new editor-in-chief.
Weiss co-founded The Free Press after leaving The New York Times.
Paramount Skydance acquired The Free Press.
Weiss is taking the helm of CBS News.
Weiss is a provocative columnist.

clusters.title: Man on trial in Albania kills judge, injures two others in shooting
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Kills Judge, Injures Others in Albanian Courtroom Shooting

items.title: Man on trial in Albania kills judge, injures two others in shooting
items.standfirst: Astrit Kalaja, an appeals court judge, died on his way to hospital after the courtroom attack on Monday.
items.content: Astrit Kalaja, an appeals court judge, died on his way to hospital after the courtroom attack on Monday.

items.title: Judge killed in courtroom shooting in Albania
items.standfirst: Man opens fire in Tirana court, killing judge and injuring two other people, and is arrested after fleeing sceneA man on trial opened fire in a courtroom in the Albanian capital, Tirana, killing the judge and injuring two other people, police have said.The judge, Astrit Kalaja, was presiding during a hearing at the court of appeal on Monday when the man opened fire, police said, adding that the shooter was promptly arrested. “The judge was rushed to the hospital, but succumbed to his injuries on the way,” a police statement said. Continue reading...
items.content: Man opens fire in Tirana court, killing judge and injuring two other people, and is arrested after fleeing sceneA man on trial opened fire in a courtroom in the Albanian capital, Tirana, killing the judge and injuring two other people, police have said.The judge, Astrit Kalaja, was presiding during a hearing at the court of appeal on Monday when the man opened fire, police said, adding that the shooter was promptly arrested. “The judge was rushed to the hospital, but succumbed to his injuries on the way,” a police statement said. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A man shot and killed a judge in an Albanian courtroom.
Two other people were injured in the shooting.
The judge, Astrit Kalaja, died on his way to the hospital.
The shooter was arrested after fleeing the scene.
The shooting occurred during a court hearing in Tirana.

clusters.title: Rugby world rallies round former England captain Lewis Moody after MND diagnosis
clusters.neutral_headline: Rugby World Rallies Round Lewis Moody After MND Diagnosis

items.title: Rugby world rallies round former England captain Lewis Moody after MND diagnosis
items.standfirst: World Cup winner diagnosed with motor neurone diseaseFundraising page set up by former Leicester teammatesThe rugby world has rallied around the former England captain Lewis Moody, who has revealed he has been diagnosed with motor neurone disease. The 47-year-old 2003 World Cup winner admitted he was having trouble accepting what his diagnosis means for the future but that he intends to stay positive.Among the most decorated forwards to play for England, he earned 71 caps and led his country at the 2011 World Cup in New Zealand, earning the nickname “Mad Dog” as an all-action, hard-hitting flanker. Continue reading...
items.content: World Cup winner diagnosed with motor neurone diseaseFundraising page set up by former Leicester teammatesThe rugby world has rallied around the former England captain Lewis Moody, who has revealed he has been diagnosed with motor neurone disease. The 47-year-old 2003 World Cup winner admitted he was having trouble accepting what his diagnosis means for the future but that he intends to stay positive.Among the most decorated forwards to play for England, he earned 71 caps and led his country at the 2011 World Cup in New Zealand, earning the nickname “Mad Dog” as an all-action, hard-hitting flanker. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Ex-New York Times writer to lead CBS after Paramount deal
clusters.neutral_headline: Ex-New York Times Writer to Lead CBS After Paramount Deal

items.title: Ex-New York Times writer to lead CBS after Paramount deal
items.standfirst: A former NYT opinion editor-turned media start-up owner Bari Weiss has been named as the next boss of CBS News after the TV channel was bought by Paramount
items.content: A former NYT opinion editor-turned media start-up owner Bari Weiss has been named as the next boss of CBS News after the TV channel was bought by Paramount

items.title: Bari Weiss named editor-in-chief of CBS News as Paramount buys Free Press startup
items.standfirst: Commentator to lead storied US news network, five years after acrimonious exit from New York TimesWho is Bari Weiss, the new editor-in-chief of CBS News?The CBS News owner Paramount will acquire the Free Press, a media startup founded by Bari Weiss, and has appointed her editor-in-chief of the storied US news network.Weiss, 41, has no experience working in broadcast television, though she has carved out a reputation as a heterodox opinion writer and burgeoning media operator. Continue reading...
items.content: Commentator to lead storied US news network, five years after acrimonious exit from New York TimesWho is Bari Weiss, the new editor-in-chief of CBS News?The CBS News owner Paramount will acquire the Free Press, a media startup founded by Bari Weiss, and has appointed her editor-in-chief of the storied US news network.Weiss, 41, has no experience working in broadcast television, though she has carved out a reputation as a heterodox opinion writer and burgeoning media operator. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Bari Weiss, a former NYT opinion editor, will lead CBS News.
Paramount bought the media startup The Free Press.
Weiss is the new editor-in-chief of CBS News.
Weiss has no experience in broadcast television.
Weiss has a reputation as a heterodox opinion writer.
